00037 #include <vector>

00039 /**
00040  * @class RMA 
00041  * @brief Holds methods for computing the popular Robust Muliarray Average of
00042  * Microarrays (RMA). 
00043  *
00044  * Implements the method described in "Exploration,
00045  * normalization, and summaries of high density oligonucleotide array probe
00046  * level data", Irizarry RA, Hobbs B, Collin F, Beazer-Barclay YD, Antonellis
00047  * KJ, Scherf U, Speed TP., Biostatistics. 2003 Apr;4(2):249-64.  Core routines
00048  * are two static functions for manipulating matrices. This class is mainly a
00049  * collection of static methods to manipulate vectors and matrices to perform an
00050  * RMA analysis. RMA really consists of three separate steps:
00051  *
00052  * 1) Background estimation which occurs at the chip level as implemented by
00053  *    backgroundCorrect(). The background subtraction is more complicated than
00054  *    a simple subtraction and accounts for a substantial amount of the code.
00055 
00056  * 2) Quantile normalization. As the original normalization module of the affy
00057  *    sdk used a different manner of resolving ties than the bioconductor version
00058  *    there are methods to normalize a matrix of chip data implemented in
00059  *    quantileNorm(). The normalization module has since been extended to reproduce
00060  *    the bioconductor results and the code here will be deprecated soon.
00061  *
00062  * 3) Probeset summary. Use the median polish algorithm to estimate the target
00063  *    response and feature response using medianPolishPsetFromMatrix(). Target
00064  *    response is used as the signal level estimates. While this is where the real
00065  *    "work" of doing probeset level estimates occurs, it takes up very little code
00066  *    as the median polish algorithm is simple to implement.
00067  */
00068 class RMA {
00069   
00070 public: 
00071   
00072 /** 
00073  * Static version of medianPolishSet for when it isn't convenient to have an RMA
00074  * instance. Note that both the the colEstimates and rowEstimates by convention
00075  * have the global median added back to them. The identifiability function used
00076  * by RMA is median(log(f)) = 0 for both feature and target effects. By
00077  * convention the global median is added back onto target estimates to avoid
00078  * negative expression summaries.  The same is done for feature effects although
00079  * subtracting off the median for a probeset will give the median(log(f)) = 0
00080  * adjusted feature effects.
00081  * 
00082  * @param pmMatrix - Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00083  *             will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00084  *             here.
00085  * @param numRow - Number of rows in the matrix.
00086  * @param numCol - Number of columns in the matrix.
00087  * @param colEstimates - Feature effects.
00088  * @param rowEstimates - Target effects.
00089  */
00090 static void medianPolishPsetFromMatrix(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &pmMatrix, 
00091                                        int numRow, int numCol, 
00092                                        std::vector<float> &colEstimates,
00093                                        std::vector<float> &rowEstimates,
00094                                        bool doLog = true);
00095 
00096 /** 
00097  * Static version of medianPolishSet for when it isn't convenient to 
00098  * have an RMA instance.
00099  * 
00100  * @param pmMatrix - Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00101  *             will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00102  *             here.
00103  * @param numRow - Number of rows in the matrix.
00104  * @param numCol - Number of columns in the matrix.
00105  * @param indexes - Indexes of the probes for probe set of interest
00106  *        into PM matrix.
00107  * @param results - Vector in which probe sets summaries, one per GeneChip,
00108  *        will be returned as log2 values.
00109  */
00110 static inline void medianPolish(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &pmMatrix,
00111                                 int numRow, int numCol, 
00112                                 std::vector<float> &colEstimates,
00113                                 std::vector<float> &rowEstimates) {
00114   medianPolishPsetFromMatrix(pmMatrix, numRow, numCol, 
00115                              colEstimates, rowEstimates);
00116 }

00119 /**
00120  * Static version of medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsOnePass
00121  * This version will use precomputed feature effects as input values and perform the usual median polish 
00122  * algorithm until convergence 
00123  *
00124  * @param pmMatrix -            Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00125  *                              will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00126  *                              here.
00127  * @param numRow -              Number of rows in the matrix.
00128  * @param numCol -              Number of columns in the matrix.
00129  * @param colEstimates -        This is the precomputed vector of probe (feature) effects.
00130  * @param rowEstimates -        This is the output vector of chip effects. 
00131  * @param doLog -               This is a boolean switch to turn on or off the computation of logs of the input matrix.
00132 
00133  */
00134   static void medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsOnePass(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &pmMatrix,
00135                                                         int numChips, int numProbes, 
00136                                                         std::vector<float> &colEstimates,
00137                                                         std::vector<float> &rowEstimates, 
00138                                                         bool doLog = true);
00139 
00140 /**
00141  * Static version of medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsUsedAsSeedValues
00142  * This version will use precomputed feature effects as input values and perform the usual median polish 
00143  * algorithm until convergence 
00144  *
00145  * @param pmMatrix -            Matrix of perfect match probe intensities. Values
00146  *                              will be modified in place, residuals will be filled in
00147  *                              here.
00148  * @param numRow -              Number of rows in the matrix.
00149  * @param numCol -              Number of columns in the matrix.
00150  * @param colEstimates -        This is the precomputed vector of probe (feature) effects.
00151  * @param rowEstimates -        This is the output vector of chip effects. 
00152  * @param doLog -               This is a boolean switch to turn on or off the computation of logs of the input matrix.
00153 
00154  */
00155   static void medianPolishWithPrecomputedEffectsUsedAsSeedValues(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &pmMatrix,
00156                                                                  int numChips, int numProbes, 
00157                                                                  std::vector<float> &colEstimates,
00158                                                                  std::vector<float> &rowEstimates, 
00159                                                                  bool doLog = true);

00232   static void colMassDist(std::vector<float> &dat, double bandWidth, double from,

00264   static void linearApprox(std::vector<float> &x, std::vector<float> &y,

00266    /** 
00267     * Here we are recreating the density() function in R with an Epanechnikov
00268     * kernel. There are three steps 1) Compute a Epanechikov kernel. 2) Convolve
00269     * the mass distribution with a fast fourier transform. 3) Linearly
00270     * interpolate the results.
00271     * @param dat - data of interest.
00272     * @param numBins - number of bins to spread data over (16384 for original
00273     *                  RMA method).
00274     * 
00275     * @return - Mode of the data.
00276     */
00277   static double modeOfData(std::vector<float> &dat, int numBins);

00282   static void printVector(std::vector<float> &dat);

00284   /** 
00285    * Do a fast fourier transform on data. Values in data vector will be
00286    * overwritten with the results. The format of data must be that of
00287    * real and imaginary numbers interleaved together. So if the real
00288    * portion of the number is at index 0, the imaginary portion will be
00289    * at index 1. The next real number is at index 2 and imaginary
00290    * portion is at index 3, etc. The input data vector must be a power
00291    * of two (i.e. 32, 64, 128, etc) if your data is not a power of two
00292    * in length you must pad it with zeros. Be warned that this bit of
00293    * code is not terribly user friendly and can be tough to work with.
00294    * 
00295    * @param dat - data of interest.
00296    * @param inverse - should we perform the inverse fourier transform?
00297    */
00298   static void fft(std::vector<float> &dat, bool inverse);
00299 
00300   /** 
00301    * Convolves the real numbers in two vectors. Fill in kerelwords with
00302    * the convolved data.
00303    * 
00304    * @param yVec - binned up data.
00305    * @param kernelWords - kernel function.
00306    * @param count - Number of entries in yVec and kernelWords. 
00307    */
00308   static void convolveDataKernel(std::vector<float> &yVec, std::vector<float> &kernelWords, int count);
00309 
00310   /** 
00311    * Calculate the parameters necesary to do the RMA background 
00312    * subtraction.
00313    * @param data - all of the data for a given cel file.
00314    * @param mu - pointer to parameter mu to be filled in by function.
00315    * @param sigma - pointer to parameter sigma to be filled in by function.
00316    * @param alpha - pointer to paramter alpha to be filled in.
00317    * @param numBins - number of bins to use in denstiy. RMA traditionally uses
00318    *                  16,384. It is essential that this number be a power of two.
00319    */
00320   static void estimateBgParam(std::vector<float> &data, double *mu, 
00321                               double *sigma, double *alpha, int numBins= 16384);
00322 
00323   /**
00324    * The "true" signal is then estimated as:
00325    * 
00326    * X = a + b(phi(a/b)/PHI(a/b))
00327    * where a = signal - mu - (sigma^2 * alpha)
00328    *       b = sigma
00329    
00330    *       phi and PHI are standard normal density function and
00331    *       distribution function respectively given as:
00332    *
00333    *       phi(z) = 1 / sqrt(2*pi) * exp(-.5*z^2)
00334    *       PHI(z) = \int_-inf^z 1 / sqrt(2*pi) exp(-.5w^2) dw
00335    * @param value original value.
00336    * @param mu - mode of "background" signal.
00337    * @param sigma - stdev of "background" signal
00338    * @param alpha - mean of exponential "true" signal
00339    * @return bg adjusted value.
00340    */
00341   static inline float bgSubData(float value, double mu, double sigma, double alpha, bool &error) {
00342     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: value " + ToStr(value) + " [in]");
00343     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: mu    " + ToStr(mu) + " [in]");
00344     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: sigma " + ToStr(sigma) + " [in]");
00345     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: alpha " + ToStr(alpha) + " [in]");
00346     value = (float)(value - mu - alpha*sigma*sigma);
00347     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: value " + ToStr(value) + " [post transformation]");
00348     float denom = float(pnorm(value/sigma));
00349     //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: denom " + ToStr(denom));
00350     if(denom == 0) {
00351         //Verbose::out(5,"bgSubData: error is set");
00352         error = true;
00353     } else 
00354         error = false;
00355     value = (float)(value + sigma * phi(value/sigma)/denom);
00356   return value;
00357   }
00358 
00359   /** 
00360    * RMA background correct subtraction. The RMA bacground subtraction
00361    * is a little complicated. The details are available in Ben Bolstad's
00362    * thesis dissertation:
00363    * http://stat-www.berkeley.edu/users/bolstad/Dissertation/Bolstad_2004_Dissertation.pdf
00364    * The basic idea is that the signal is exponential and the background
00365    * is additive gaussian. There are a lot of fun integrals to show that
00366    * the joint distribution can be found to estimate the true signal
00367    * given the observed signal on the chip and the parameters mu and
00368    * sigma for the background and alpha for the exponential. Estimating
00369    * mu, sigma and alpha explicitly is difficult though so RMA uses an
00370    * ad-hoc method where mu is estimated as the mode of the data, sigma
00371    * is estimated by the variation in the lower 50% quantile tail and
00372    * alpha is estimated as an exponential fit to the upper 50% quantile
00373    * tail. The "true" signal is then estimated as:
00374    * 
00375    * X = a + b(phi(a/b)/PHI(a/b))
00376    * where a = signal - mu - (sigma^2 * alpha)
00377    *       b = sigma
00378    
00379    *       phi and PHI are standard normal density function and
00380    *       distribution function respectively given as:
00381    *
00382    *       phi(z) = 1 / sqrt(2*pi) * exp(-.5*z^2)
00383    *       PHI(z) = \int_-inf^z 1 / sqrt(2*pi) exp(-.5w^2) dw
00384    * 
00385    * Note that this all happens on a per chip basis.
00386    * @param data - vector of data for a chip. 
00387    * @param numBins - number of bins to use for estimating mode
00388    *    of data for background parameters. Must be a power of 2.
00389    */
00390   static void backgroundCorrect(std::vector<float> &data, int numBins = 16384);
00391

00399    */
00400   static void getRowEffect(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &psMatrix,
00401                            int numRow, int numCol,
00402                            std::vector<float> &rowEffect);

00462   /** 
00463    * Standard normal probability density function.
00464    * @param x - value of interest.
00465    * @return - density at value supplied. Specifically: 1/sqrt(2*pi)*exp(-0.5*x^2)
00466    */
00467   static double phi(double x);
00468 
00469   /** 
00470    * The cdf function for standard normal distribution consistant with Bolstad's
00471    * RMA notatation. Also see pnorm.
00472    * @param x - value.
00473    * @return - probability that standard normal value has
00474    * probability <= x.
00475    */
00476   static double PHI(double x);

00481    * @return - probability that value is < z.

00483   static double pnorm(double z);

00500   static void quantileNorm(std::vector< std::vector<float> > &data);
